mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Experiences of Perfectionistic Collegiate Classical Musicians

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Classical musicians perform in a domain where success and failure hinges on the opinions of others. Thus, the value of perfection in pursuit of high performance is commonly ingrained in musicians early in their training. Much of the quantitative research on perfectionism focuses on outcomes, but qualitative investigations can help to advance understanding of the experiences of different types of perfectionists in competitive settings (Gotwals & Spencer-Cavaliere, 2014; Hill et al., 2015; Howle & Eklund, 2017; Mallison-Howard et al., 2018; Sellars et al., 2016; Stoeber, 2011). Therefore, the primary purpose of this study was to further understand the experiences of perfectionism by exploring collegiate classical musicians' perceptions, sources, and consequences of perfectionism. The secondary purpose was to develop a model that can be applied to understand both Mixed Perfectionists' and Pure-Personal Standards Perfectionists' experiences. Self-identified Mixed Perfectionists and Pure-Personal Standards Perfectionists (n=12) from a collegiate saxophone studio were interviewed for this study. Participants also completed a demographics assessment and the Sport-Multidimensional Perfectionism Scale-2 (Gotwols & Dunn, 2009). A grounded theory approach was used to guide data analysis and propose the "Dynamics of the Experiences of Perfectionism Model" (Strauss & Corbin, 1998). The category labeled perceptions was identified as the core phenomenon of the model, meaning that the entire experience of perfectionism hinges on the performer's perceptions. Several factors were found to play a role in participants' experiences of perfectionism. These factors included early experiences, personal standards, concerns over mistakes, perceptions of self, perceptions of the environment, perceptions of the director and peers, definitions of effective performance, preparation, appraisals, perceptions of the audience, attributions, and emotional and behavioral consequences. The proposed model explains how these factors build off each other and layer in a way that illustrates the development of perfectionism and perfectionistic tendencies over time. Results are discussed in relationship to the previous literature along with highlighting applications for music program directors and faculty, musicians, and potential intervention points for mental performance consultants.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
classical, mental, perfectionism, performance, saxophone, sport psychology
Robert E. Eklund, Professor Directing Dissertation; Joshua Newman, University Representative; Svenja A. Wolf, Committee Member; Jeannine Turner, Committee Member.
